title: Bernie Sanders Won the Debate
summary: He may not be the nominee, but he has set the Democratic agenda.. President Trump is a lucky man. Typically a re-election campaign is a referendum on the incumbent, and Mr. Trump is losing that race. But the Democrats are moving left so rapidly that they may let him turn 2020 into a choice between his policy record and the most extreme liberal agenda since 1972 (which may be unfair to George McGovern).

title: How Supreme Got Pulled Into a Fight for Its Billion-Dollar Brand
summary: Resume Subscription. Supreme, an underground streetwear brand, has attracted a cultlike following among teens seeking hard-to-get looks by keeping its products scarce. title: Idaho Quits Worrying About Snails
summary: A spring cleaning of the state regulatory code has killed 900 pages.. If there were a competition to find the nation's most useless regulation, Idaho would have strong contenders. summary: Justices Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh staked out differences in tone and priorities in just-completed term. title: 17 Rules for Your Fourth of July Cookout
summary: You've been tasked with grill duty. Don't panic. We've got you covered.. Congratulations! You've been entrusted with grilling duties on the Fourth of July. This is major, my friend. Grill master is the most prestigious position at the cookout. And there's only one unbreakable rule: Don't screw it up. People are hungry, tipsy and depending on you to prevent the holiday from devolving into a fiasco.

title: The Troubles Beneath the Surface of California's Comeback
summary: There's a budget surplus, but also homelessness, lousy schools, expensive housing and even typhus.. A decade ago many conservatives watched with delight as deep-blue California struggled beneath double-digit unemployment and gaping budget deficits. But the schadenfreude faded as the Golden State's fiscal and economic picture brightened-at least on paper. Unemployment has dipped to 4.2%, and the state this year recorded a $21 billion surplus, due in part to a 2012 tax hike on the wealthy. Gov. Gavin Newsom this week signed a $215 billion budget that boosts spending on housing, schools and child care. It even includes a sales-tax exemption for diapers.

title: Knitwits and Joe Biden's Busing History
summary: With an eye on 2020, liberals wonder if their views on race have become too extreme.. J. Anthony Lukas was the reporter every young reporter wanted to be after he produced, in 1985, "Common Ground," a meticulous and nuanced book on the busing fight in Boston.

title: EU, South American Countries Reach Agreement on Trade
summary: Pact would forge bloc of 780 million people. The European Union and four South American countries clinched a deal Friday that would create a trade bloc of 780 million people, representing a quarter of the world's economy.

title: 'Songs of America' and 'A Fiery Gospel' Review: Of Thee We Sing
summary: At moments of national distress, music often unites us more profoundly than mere words or images.. A Pulitzer prize-winning biographer, a Grammy Award-winning country-music star, lavish illustrations on glossy, coated stock: It all makes for such an impressive package that the contents of "Songs of America," though fitfully compelling, are somewhat disappointing. Author Jon Meacham and singer Tim McGraw, neighbors in Nashville, Tenn., are dismayed by the "ferocious partisanship" that divides Americans "as rarely, if ever, before." (More than the Civil War?) They hope that recalling parts of our musical heritage-from the 1760s to the Obama administration-can help bridge some of our differences. "Nativism, xenophobia, cultural populism, and broad political fear," Mr. Meacham concedes, "have shaped the republic from the beginning and likely always will." Still, a major impetus behind "Songs of America"-and the man the authors hold largely responsible for exacerbating our differences today, though never named-is President Obama's successor.

title: Political Books: My Country-Right, Left and Center
summary: For Adam Gopnik, liberals are not on the left but in the middle, flanked by radicals and rightists.. Add this to Donald Trump's unintentional achievements: He has obliged American liberals to reconsider their disdain for nationalism. Two years ago, this column considered Mark Lilla's "The Once and Future Liberal," in which the author lamented his fellow liberals' increasing inability to appreciate the virtues of national solidarity. Unlike Mr. Lilla, who blamed the right's love of free-market individualism and the left's sudden infatuation with identity politics, Jill Lepore doesn't blame anybody. In "This America: The Case for the Nation" (Liveright, 150 pages, $16.95), Ms. Lepore only says that "historians" and "scholars" have neglected the nation-state in favor of either demographic subdivisions (race, class, sex) or supranational and global phenomena. "Nations, to make sense of themselves," she writes, "need some kind of agreed-upon past. They can get it from scholars or they can get it from demagogues, but get it they will." No prizes for guessing which demagogue she has in mind.

title: 'Marius Petipa' Review: The Imperial Ballet Master
summary: The first life of Petipa in English, Nadine Meisner work is engaging, well-researched and strong on context.. The instructions received were at once specific and allusive: 16 bars of music here to arouse expectations, 24 bars there for a "haughty and finicky" dance. In one place, hunting horns were called for; in another, music suggesting the "rays of the setting sun." A "little coquettish adagio" should give way to a coda in a style reminiscent of Mendelssohn. So strongly did Tchaikovsky believe in "The Sleeping Beauty," the project he was working on, that he took pains to follow these instructions as closely and imaginatively as possible. Equally great was his respect for the man who issued them, the ballet master Marius Petipa.

title: S&P 500 Posts Best First Half in 22 Years
summary: A banner June followed a dismal May; S&P ends second quarter up 3.8% and has risen 17% in 2019. Stocks notched solid gains in the second quarter thanks to a perceived shift in the Federal Reserve's appetite for interest-rate cuts, extending a rally that propelled the S&P 500 to record highs.

title: 'Life Finds a Way' and 'Good Enough' Review: The Drive to Thrive
summary: Evolution is a process of solving real-world problems, not achieving abstract ideals. Some solutions are just good enough.. Human beings are well adapted critters, but hardly perfect. Our knees and lower backs are frequent problems, a man's prostate is awkwardly close to his urethra (sometimes requiring surgery), a woman's birth canal is sometimes too small for an infant's head (necessitating Caesarean delivery). In sum, we were not "intelligently designed" but are the products of an evolutionary path filled with twists and turns, chance events and accidents. The process of natural selection maximizes fitness but is limited by what came before.

title: Oregon Republicans to Come Out of Hiding
summary: With climate bill effectively dead, senators will return from Idaho. Oregon's Republican state senators agreed to return to the Capitol Friday, after a week on the run to stop Democrats from passing a landmark climate bill.

title: Kenney Led Merrill's Push Into Investment Banking
summary: Executive broadened a firm that had focused mainly on individual investors and helped it make a bundle on Bloomberg. When Merrill Lynch & Co. bought White Weld & Co. in 1978, one of the employees it obtained was an investment-research specialist named Jerome P. Kenney. He stayed at Merrill for three decades and helped transform it from a firm mainly focused on selling stocks to mom-and-pop investors across America into a giant in the institutional market able to compete with Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley .

title: Supreme Court Decisions for This Term
summary: How the court ruled on key cases in the 2018-19 term, its first with Justice Brett Kavanaugh. The Supreme Court opened a new chapter in its 2018-19 term, after Brett Kavanaugh assumed the seat held for 30 years by Justice Anthony Kennedy. Although Justice Kennedy frequently cast the deciding vote on a court closely divided by ideology, Justice Kavanaugh's conservative pedigree suggested he would be a more dependable member of an ascendant bloc on the right. The court's caseload, however, was relatively light on polarizing legal disputes, softening, whether by accident or design, the impact of President Trump's second appointee.

summary: Larry Fox's dismal tale regarding the potential loss of hundreds of employees in his restaurants due to the well-meaning yet misguided efforts of politicians to raise the minimum wage simply underscores how "social justice" warriors in government are disconnected from the real world.. Larry Fox's dismal tale regarding the potential loss of hundreds of employees in his restaurants due to the well-meaning yet misguided efforts of politicians to raise the minimum wage simply underscores how "social justice" warriors in government are disconnected from the real world ("The $15 Minimum Wage Will Put Me Out of Business," Cross Country, June 22). title: Plugging in the Wind Is a Complicated Issue
summary: People invariably love the idea of better, more reliable energy transmission-as long as the line goes elsewhere.. Ours is a nation that makes opposition far easier than support, and that's the primary reason our electric grid is antiquated and undersized.

title: White Roses Are Part of the 9/11 Memorial
summary: Each morning one of our Visitors Services staff members places white roses in the names of those whose birthdays fall on that day.. title: Heart Disease Rise and Nutrition Guidelines
summary: Perhaps the medical establishment needs to reconsider its war on animal fat. Humans evolved for a fatty diet; only recently have sugars and starches become widely available. Most adults won't restrict fats without increasing carbohydrates.. Regarding "Heart Disease Roars Back" (Page One, June 22): Perhaps the medical establishment needs to reconsider its war on animal fat. Humans evolved for a fatty diet; only recently have sugars and starches become widely available. Most adults won't restrict fats without increasing carbohydrates-we have to get our calories somewhere. A diet without either animal fat or sweeteners is very boring, so we've gotten millions of Americans off meat and onto a high-carb diet. I would like to see more research on low-glycemic-load diets in our population of overweight adults, especially diabetics.

title: Martin Shkreli's Lawyers Ask Judges to Toss Conviction

title: Berlin's Newest Art Temple
summary: The James-Simon-Galerie is a gateway to the city's Museum Island.. Berlin's Museum Island, a complex of five museums clustered at the northern tip of a narrow island in the city's Spree River, houses a significant number of Germany's cultural treasures. Declared a Unesco World Heritage site in 1999, it has in fact been a work in progress for just about the whole of its 180-year history. Now it has grown to include a new building, the James-Simon-Galerie, which will celebrate its formal opening on July 12 in the presence of German Chancellor Angela Merkel, before opening to the public the next day.

title: 'The Spirit of Inquiry' Review: Inventing the Scientist
summary: A history of the Cambridge Philosophical Society, a forum for the 'spirit of inquiry' founded 200 years ago this year.. We like to tell tales of scientific discovery as if they were mostly the work of heroic individuals, thrust into glorious awareness during moments of epiphany: Archimedes figuring out how to measure the volume of objects while taking a bath and then running naked through the streets of Syracuse shouting "Eureka!"; young Newton bonked on the head by a falling apple and thus coming up with the idea of the law of gravity; Darwin glimpsing the outlines of natural selection in the beaks of unsuspecting Galápagos finches; Marie Curie's lab illuminated, on a dark December night in Paris, by the bluish glow of the new element radium. The reality was often quite different: For example, it took the services of John Gould, preserver of the collections at the London Zoological Society, to help Darwin understand what he had seen in the Galápagos (Gould quite appropriately excoriated him for not taking better notes).

title: 'The Last Pirate of New York' Review: New York's Original Gangster
summary: The 19th century is often regarded as America's golden age of arts, literature and commerce, but we often forget that it was also a golden age of crime.. The 19th century is justifiably regarded as America's golden age, a formative time of progress in the arts, literature and the building of a commercial empire. But we often forget that the century was also a golden age of crime. Americans were periodically obsessed with the details of spectacular criminal cases-the 1812 disappearance of Russell Colvin in Vermont, the 1836 murder of New York prostitute Helen Jewett, the 1892 Lizzie Borden ax murders in Massachusetts-that enriched the tabloid-news business and revealed a national character that was a curious mélange of Victorian morals and salacious interest in violent crime.

title: Five Best: Tim Bouverie on the British Appeasement of Adolf Hitler
summary: Selected by the author of 'Appeasement: Chamberlain, Hitler, Churchill and the Road to War.'. Edited by Robert Self (2005)

title: Apple's Shine Goes Only So Far Now
summary: Departure of design guru Jony Ive emblematic of big challenges the company now faces. Apple Inc. needs Jony Ive less these days. Just what the iconic device maker really requires now is much less clear.

title: Taking on Biden, Harris Makes Her Mark
summary: Confronting Democratic front-runner over racial issues gives California senator a starring role in the second debate. Sen. Kamala Harris proved she can command a debate stage by confronting former Vice President Joe Biden over questions of racial equality in a strong performance that could boost her standing in the crowded Democratic nomination contest.

title: Children's Books: Boys of the Great War
summary: Gripping tales of wartime sabotage and jungle survival.. Imagining the Western Front, most of us think of vast stretches of ruined farmland, deep trenches, and a no man's land strung with barbed wire and strewn with bodies. We are less likely to picture what lay beneath these World War I horrors: a network of narrow tunnels in which thousands of Allied men and boys burrowed toward the enemy in near darkness and total silence.

title: Was Stonewall a 'Riot'? A Term for Violent Acts Has Spurred Its Own Revolt
summary: Deciding what to call rebellions through history is more than a matter of semantics; it has become a deeply political act. This week marks the 50th anniversary of an incident that many contend gave rise to the modern gay rights movement: the unrest that erupted on June 28, 1969, when New York City police raided the Stonewall Inn, a gay bar on Christopher Street in Greenwich Village. The resistance to the police crackdown inspired activists to mobilize, propelling the gay liberation movement.

title: Mysteries: The Sudden Vacancies Down the Hall
summary: In Riley Sager's psychological thriller, disturbing disappearances disrupt life in a storied Manhattan apartment-building.. In Riley Sager's psychological thriller "Lock Every Door" (Dutton, 368 pages, $26), New York's century-old Bartholomew apartment building-"a sliver of stone rising thirteen stories over Central Park West"-has been home over the decades to the famous and the well-to-do. It is, in the somewhat hyperbolic words of a current resident, "one of the most famous buildings on the planet." Jules Larsen, the 25-year-old narrator of this book, can't believe her good fortune at being offered the job of apartment-sitter in one of the Bartholomew's finest suites-with a salary of $4,000 a month.

title: 'Deep River' Review: In the Heart of the Forest Primeval
summary: Set amid the loggers, labor organizers and immigrant families of early 20th-century Washington, this is 'a big American novel.'. Karl Marlantes's first novel, "Matterhorn," was the story of a unit of U.S. Marines ordered to establish, abandon, and retake a hilltop firebase during the Vietnam War. Mr. Marlantes, a decorated veteran of that disastrous conflict, had personal acquaintance with such bootless operations, with the high-level callousness, bureaucratic incompetence, pervasive racism, troop demoralization and lethal bungling that characterized that war. His second novel comes almost a decade later, and although it involves a similar disregard for men's lives, it deals with a very different subject, the Finnish and Swedish immigrants who provided much of the labor for the timber industry in the Pacific Northwest in the first part of the 20th century.

title: Fiction: The Great Migration North
summary: A mass exodus of blacks from a fictional Southern state leaves the abandoned whites bereft of identity.. A couple of years ago, New Yorker staff writer Kathryn Schultz came out with an article about the late and largely forgotten writer William Melvin Kelley (1937-2017) after a chance encounter with his name led her to read his debut novel. In the wake of her enthusiastic rediscovery, Anchor Books has now reissued that work, titled "A Different Drummer" (205 pages, $16) and originally published in 1962. It is by such quirks of fortune that novels-even great ones-survive to find new readers.

title: OPEC to Extend Cuts Amid Dual Threats to Oil Supply, Demand
summary: As OPEC prepares to roll over cuts, Saudis to press Iraq, Nigeria for better compliance. OPEC is set to extend its oil production cuts into the second half of this year, cartel and Saudi officials said, as the group and its allies contend with Middle East tensions that threaten crude supply and economic weakness in China that could crimp demand.

title: Vatican Encourages Chinese Catholic Priests to Register With Beijing
summary: Pope Francis has been trying to accommodate the government in his quest to overcome the disunity of Catholicism in China. ROME-The Vatican is encouraging Catholic bishops and priests in China to register with state authorities, a sign of the pope's bigger push for rapprochement with Beijing even at a cost to the church's independence.

title: Apple Shifts Mac Pro Production to China
summary: The $6,000 desktop computer had been the company's only major device assembled in the U.S.. Apple Inc. is manufacturing its new Mac Pro computer in China, according to people familiar with its plans, shifting abroad production of what had been its only major device assembled in the U.S. as trade tensions escalate between the Trump administration and Beijing.

title: Deutsche Bank Considers Up to 20,000 Job Cuts
summary: Job losses would likely take place over more than a year, with the pain and costs spread across regions and businesses. Deutsche Bank AG is weighing whether to cut 15,000 to 20,000 jobs, or more than one in six full-time positions globally, according to a person familiar with high-level discussions about the latest attempts to turn around the struggling financial giant.

title: U.S. Inflation Continues Recovery but Remains Below Fed Target
summary: Trend could ease central bank's worries about weak price pressures. WASHINGTON-U.S. inflation continued to recover in May from a sharp slowdown earlier this year, a trend that could ease the Federal Reserve's worries about weak price pressures while potentially tempering investors' hopes for an interest-rate cut next month.

title: Star Manager Woodford Pledges to Cut Borrowing
summary: Listed investment trust also tries to assuage concerns over asset values. LONDON-A fund run by star investor Neil Woodford is aiming to slash its debt and pledged to recruit more independent directors to its board while it attempts to assuage investor concerns over the value of its investments.

title: How One Nonprofit Is Using Venture-Capital Tactics to Help Save Africa's Last 20,000 Wild Lions
summary: In an era of Instagram-length attention spans, wildlife conservation philanthropies are trying new tactics to bring urgent attention to threatened species. Actress Michelle Rodriguez, model Jordan Barrett and photographer Gray Sorrenti band together to pitch in.. ON JORDAN BARRETT'S FIRST TRIP to Africa last year to visit an elephant reserve in Samburu, Kenya, he arrived with only a tuxedo. The model had come straight from the Cannes Film Festival, and his luggage got lost en route. For Barrett's second trip, this past February, he was outfitted more appropriately, having stockpiled enough army surplus khakis and cargoes to carry him through two weeks on Namibia's Skeleton Coast tracking desert lions-of the 20,000 wild lions left in Africa, there are only 150 desert lions-on a trip coordinated in part by the Wildlife Conservation Network (WCN). The 22-year-old Australian, who has fronted campaigns for Tom Ford and Versace, is adding ambassador of the WCN's Lion Recovery Fund (LRF) to his résumé.

title: To Sort Anbang's Assets, Chinese Authorities Create Dajia
summary: The creation of a new entity signals a further push by authorities to sort out the company's assets, some of which are being sold off to raise cash. BEIJING-Chinese authorities have formed a new company to take over assets of Anbang Insurance Group Co., laying the groundwork for a new phase of restructuring for the troubled company.

title: Forget Montreal. The Tampa Bay Rays Should Move to...London?
summary: The Rays are in the market for a new home. Baseball is coming to London this weekend. And there's even precedent for a Florida-England team: the Jacksonville Jaguars. Almost 15 years ago, Adam Sampson joined a fantasy baseball league. This would have been completely normal, except that he lived in London and knew next to nothing about the sport played across the pond. He spent most of his time obsessing over Leyton Orient F.C., a club that's in the fourth division of English soccer, and he decided paying attention to baseball couldn't be any more pointless.

title: Privilege Dispute in Walmart Probe Raises Stakes for Corporate Cooperation
summary: An appeals court last year said allowing prosecutors to subpoena a former general counsel of Walmart would discourage other companies from cooperating. A legal dispute that arose during a seven-year foreign bribery probe into Walmart Inc. may have a lasting impact on how companies handle future investigations.

title: Lego Owner, Blackstone to Buy Madame Tussauds
summary: Kirkbi forms a consortium with U.S. private-equity firm to buy the rest of Merlin Entertainments, the world's No. 2 visitor-attraction operator. The family behind toy giant Lego A/S is teaming up with Blackstone Group LP and a Canadian pension fund to buy the operator of Madame Tussauds wax museums and Legoland theme parks in a deal that values the business at £4.77 billion ($6.04 billion).

title: Troubled Boeing Is Still a World-Beater
summary: Despite the 737 MAX's grounding, U.S. plane maker's broader palette gives it strength Airbus lacks. Big menus may have fallen out of favor in restaurants, which now tend to rely on a few crowd-pleasers. But they are still the likely path to success for troubled plane maker Boeing .

title: Investors Are Too Thirsty for Utility Stocks
summary: Money managers are reluctant to make a definitive call on the stock market, which has pushed too much money into sectors seen as bond proxies. It is hard to know whether to like the stock market when economic data remain decent but geopolitical tensions flare up, so investors have found a compromise: utility companies. But this strategy may be getting out of hand.

OSAKA, Japan-President Trump struck a conciliatory tone on some trade issues at the Group of 20 summit here Friday, and world leaders called on the U.S. and China to work out their differences.

title: The Man Who Wants America to Fall in Love With OPEC
summary: Mohammad Barkindo has transformed what had been a largely technical position into one with geopolitical clout; now he is courting the U.S.. In the last three years, OPEC's Mohammad Barkindo has bowed in prayer alongside Saudi Arabia's King Salman, dined with Iranian President Hassan Rouhani, visited with Vladimir Putin in the Kremlin and met with high-ranking U.S. State Department officials.

title: Facebook's Libra Cryptocurrency: How It Stacks Up to Bitcoin and PayPal
summary: The social-media giant's new payment system is a lot closer to traditional web-commerce systems than you might think. Facebook Inc. last week unveiled plans to launch Libra, a payment system it describes as a new "global currency." It's based on blockchain, the same technology that powers bitcoin, and is backed by real assets and pegged to stable government securities. Over two dozen corporate partners are on board, including financial companies MasterCard Inc., Visa Inc., PayPal Holdings Inc. and Coinbase. Partners contribute a membership fee of $10 million each. Facebook's goal is to line up a total of 100 corporate partners and $1 billion in assets.

title: Democratic Debates Sorted the Field, But Did They Persuade Voters?
summary: The debates also helped identify the main issue dividing the Democratic Party's two camps: health care. Messy as they were, the first set of Democratic presidential debates did their job: They helped sort out the party's giant field of candidates. They showed there's a distinct progressive camp, which is colliding, noisily, with a centrist camp. They also identified the main issue-health care-that divides these two camps.

title: Biden Draws Bulk of Attacks in Second Debate

Former Vice President Joe Biden faced challenges from a new generation of presidential hopefuls who took aim at his decadeslong record and questioned whether the party's Obama-era policies have gone far enough.

summary: Some Democrats had demanded changes to the legislation, which funds food, shelter, and medical care for migrants. WASHINGTON-The House passed a $4.6 billion bill funding humanitarian aid for migrants at the southern border, approving the Senate version of the legislation over the objections of nearly 100 Democrats and sending it to President Trump for his signature.
